q18: Reader:  Below is my honest thoughts on improving this course (hey you asked me...). These are the opinions of a student who may not fully understand the intentions or expectations of the professional who is teaching this course. These opinions were not developed out of laziness or unwillingness to do  extra work. They were concived in the interest of learning more effectively and with less agrivation. :)  I feel that Dr. Briggs is an excellent teacher. If there were something to improve it would be the dependancy on offoce hours. There seemed to be half (slight exaggeration) of the class in his office during office hours to get help with homework or sample problems. Dr Briggs is an excellent teacher and does explain the material well during lectures. However due to the complex nature and difficulty of the material very little is digested during the lecture reqireing a lot of thought and explination to fully grasp the concepts. I would suggest two things to help with this. A) hold office hours in a class room. Have someone ask their question to those attending. See if another student can answer the question. Correct the teaching students when needed or go over that material in more depth with those in attendance. NOTE: Maybe suplement the lecture notes with the material covered in office hours if it was to vague or miss understood? B) offer additional supplemental learning aids with worked out examples of problems with answers written out in the same format as required in webassign. Webassign is a great tool for teachers but it has limmitations: i) It is extremely picky with the formatting of the answer. If you do not know exactly what is being asked (because we are not phd's :) ) then it is easy to have the right answer and get it wrong because we are not familiar with the correct format. ii) do a brief overview of each problem type in the homework in class. While the struggle helps you learn there was a lot more stuggle with not knowing what the question was even asking. For example if the question was asking for a color and you thought it was asking for the name of a fruit then you will get that question wrong even though you are capable of answering the color question if you knew that was what was asked. This could be prevented by explaining the problem and question in more depth on WA or going over them in class to clearly explain what is needed.
